section.title: Versioning Definitions
section.para: To track and audit any changes to the CentOS Studio files that are critical to the definition, configuration and scripts of a system, use a revision control system, such as Subversion, Git or Mercurial. The Red Hat-based Linux operating system' that CentOS Studio works with by default (RHEL and CentOS) have the revision control system Subversion (svn) available by default.

While everything could be revision controlled, there are some key non-image files that should be. Within the CentOS Studio infrastructure and system building process, candidates for revision control include configuration files, system definitions and scripts, i.e. files that contain critical textual information that may change over time or are commonly used to define aspects of multiple systems, such as common repositories or network configuration.

If you decide to not use a revision control system, you could rename the solution definition or other key files every time you make a change to help you "version" your solution. You can also enter comments in the files. Keep in mind that changing the name of system definition file does not mean CentOS Studio will build a new solution. As long as the $ID remains the same, the solution remains the same.
